text: Welcome to Exploring Computing.

Post.

And then, in

to just emphasize, as I've
been doing throughout,

this idea that you want to
use your cascading style

sheet to set up
your presentation,

and that particularly
with grid-based layout,

you can get a lot of flexibility
by putting the presentation

information in the
cascading style sheet

and having the
semantic information,

like what is a heading,
what are particular sections

semantically, like in this
particular case, which section

is the Politics section,
which section is the World

section, which section
is the National section.

By putting that semantic
information in the HTML

and then pulling the
presentation information

in the cascading style sheets,
you get a lot of flexibility.

So I'm going to just go
ahead and set the body
color to f7f7f7.

So remember, those are
our hexadecimal digits.

The first f7 is for red,
the second f7 is for green,
and the third f7 is for blue.

And because the amount of red,
green, and blue is the same,
we've got a shade of gray.

And we're going to see
that the entire Washington

Post is designed around
different shades of gray.

So any time you see
those pairs repeated,

those pairs of
hexadecimal digits

repeated, that's gray,
different shades, but all gray.

And in addition, I've

to set to sans serif.

So everything that we're seeing
here, this is inside of a div

called lower section, which
represents this bottom section

of The Washington Post which
we're trying to reproduce here.

And you can see that I've said
that everything in the lower

section is going to be
laid out with a grid,

and I've had the columns
set to 1fr, 1fr, 1fr.

I'm not setting the
rows, which defaults

to auto, which means that the
rows will increase or decrease

in size based on the elements
that I placed inside of them.

So you may recall that
fr stands for fractional,

and so what 1fr,
1fr, 1fr means is

that we've got three
columns, and the space

available from the web
browser will be evenly divided
among those three columns.

So whether we've got a
relatively modestly width web

browser window or we have a
really wide web browser window,

we've still got
those three columns,

and things will expand or
contract out as necessary.

You may notice also that
the images on the right

are actually wider and taller
than the images on the left.

And so this is
something we're actually
going to have to account for.

If the images were fixed
size, but the columns were

able to increase or
decrease in width,

we'd get some odd effects, and
we don't want that to happen.

So we do need to get
those images to widen out

as the web browser window
increases and the fr's increase

the space of each
of the columns.

both of those.

there.

I'm going to use on all of them.

So remember, use ID if you've

placement on a grid.

It seems pretty

want to place several items on

That wouldn't make sense.

OK, so in this case, I'm giving

image, and I'm going to go ahead
and set the style, the width
style, to 100%.

And so what this
is going to do is

this is going to increase
the size of the image width

to however much space is
available to it by whatever
element it's contained within.

And the reason why I set the
width to 100% is, remember,

we're setting the
columns to 1 fr each.

And as the web page widens,
the fr's increase in width,

and so I want these images
to increase or decrease

in size depending on how
wide the column they're
placed within is.

And so by setting
the image width

to 100%, if that column gets
wide, the image gets wide.

And since I'm not
setting a height,

the height and width will
increase proportionately

to the proper proportions
based on the original image.
